Award.AwardTitle: Computations in Equivariant Homotopy and Algebraic K-Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1207774, Principal Investigator: Michael A. Hill

This project seeks to broaden our knowledge of equivariant computations and, by universality of certain maps, of the homotopy groups of spheres. Equivariant homotopy calculations are notoriously difficult, hybridizing representation theory and classical stable homotopy theory in beautiful, and sometimes mysterious, ways. The recent solution by the principal investigator, Hopkins, and Ravenel to the Kervaire Invariant One problem introduced several new tools and techniques to equivariant homotopy, rigidifying earlier homotopical work and generalizing naturally occurring filtrations. In this project, the PI intends to use these new, exciting tools to continue making computational inroads in equivariant homotopy. There are two main approaches: computing equivariant homotopy groups of the families of spectra introduced by the PI, Hopkins, and Ravenel, and reconceptualizing parts of the cyclotomic trace approaches to algebraic K-theory. The former uses slice filtration techniques to tackle spectra like the Hopkins-Miller spectra, allowing a direct attack on the stable homotopy groups of spheres from a non-traditional approach. The latter builds on the norm machinery to rewrite the classical constructions in the equivariant approaches to algebraic K-theory, recasting them in computationally more amenable forms.

The project addresses directly the heart of algebraic topology: computing numbers and invariants to understand spaces. The goal of algebraic topology is to systematically build a connection between algebraic objects like numbers and geometric objects like spaces. Equivariant algebraic topology remembers a collection of symmetries inherent in a space as part of the data, systematically grouping spaces with the same symmetries, and the numbers and invariants produced must reflect this. Remembering the extra structure makes richer, but more complicated, computations, and it allows us to tease apart otherwise interconnected problems. For example, using equivariant methods, the principal investigator, Hopkins, and Ravenel solved the Kervaire Invariant One problem, the oldest outstanding problem in algebraic topology with roots dating back to the 1930s. This in turn gave information about how we can build spaces out of simpler ones like spheres. This project aims to build on the techniques developed in the solution, tackling other computational problems in algebra and topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Loosely speaking, algebraic topology studies the ways one can attach invariants like numbers or groups to spaces in a way that allows us to distinguish spaces by kinds of intrinsic data. In the mid 20th century, algebraic topologist shifted focus to better understanding how these invariants themselves interact, starting with the development of "stable homotopy theory". This was an incredibly powerful shift, as it allowed tools from other disciplines like algebraic geometry to be imported and reinterpreted in algebraic topology, providing new intuition and creating new kinds of tools for distinguishing spaces.

Modern stable homotopy theory heavily utilizes the fact that the stable homotopy category behaves like a derived category of modules. The ground ring here is the sphere spectrum S0, and computing its homotopy groups is one of the biggest problems in the subject. The problem can be approached by first looking p-locally, and we can pass to the p-local stable homotopy category. If X is a finite cell complex, a complex which behaves like a finitely generated module over the sphere, then there is a convergent filtration of X where the layers of the filtration are further refinements of p-localization that occur only topologically: the localizations with respect to the Morava K-theories K(n) as n varies. When X is the sphere, then there are surprisingly good approximations to the K(n)-local sphere built out of homotopy fixed point spectra for finite groups acting on the Lubin-Tate spectrum. These give rise to the higher real K-theory spectra EOn of Hopkins and Miller, and understanding the homotopy groups of these spectra was a major part of the PI's research program.

In general, computing the homotopy groups of homotopy fixed points and their more rigid notion of honest fixed points is very difficult. One of the most exciting new tools developed to solve the Kervaire problem is a general slice filtration, a method which directly computes homotopy groups of fixed points. For spectra like the higher real K-theory spectra, the slice machinery greatly facilitates understanding their homotopy groups, providing direct, geometric approaches to computations. Understanding the slice filtration more generally has been another facet of the PI's program.

The passage to equivariant homotopy introduces further subtleties: in the equivariant context, there are many different notions of "commutative". In particular, the expected Zariski site for an equivariant commutative ring spectrum is much more confusing than in ordinary algebraic geometry. Teasing apart the exact structure and how to work with it has been another key aspect of the PI's research program.

Finally, equivariant homotopy is also central to the homotopical approach to algebraic K-theory. There is a tower of spectra, the TR tower, built inductively out of fixed point spectra for topological Hochschild homology. Algebraic K groups are also exceedingly difficult to compute, but the new equivariant machinery provides alternate, simpler constructions to approximate this and to build relative versions.

The PI has also been very active in community-building in algebraic topology and in mathematics in general. The PI coorganized the first semester long program in algebraic topology at MSRI in 25 years. As part of this, the PI coorganized a week-long workshop at MSRI and two summer schools for graduate students and early-career researchers (one at MSRI and one at CIMAT in Mexico). The 2 summer schools included "skill building" components, helping students navigate graduate school and prepare for applying for academic jobs.

Additionally, the PI cofounded "Spectra: the organization for LGBT mathematicians", a national organization for LGBTQ+ mathematicians and their allies. This organization held a panel about being out in academia at the joint mathematics meetings in 2015 and organized the LGBT social gatherings at the 2016 joint mathematics meetings.
